contentrichtext.text: [[File:Arms Braose.png|right|thumb|alt =graphic|Arms of Reginald de Braose]] '''Reginald de Braose''' (died June 1228) was one of the sons of [[William de Braose, 4th Lord of Bramber]] and Matilda, also known as [[Maud de Braose|Maud de St. Valery]] and Lady de la Haie. Her other children included William and Giles.<ref>Oxford Dictionary of National Biography under '''Briouze [Braose], William (III) de'''</ref> The de Braoses were loyal to King [[Richard I of England|Richard I]] but grew in power under [[King]] [[John of England]]. The dynasty was in conflict with King John towards the end of his reign and almost lost everything. Reginald de Braose was a scion of the powerful [[Welsh Marches|Marcher]] family of de Braose, helped manage its survival and was also related by marriage to the [[Welsh people|Welsh]] [[Princes of Wales]]. == Magna Carta == He supported his brother [[Giles de Braose]] in his rebellions against King John. Both brothers were active against the King in the Baron's War. Neither was present at the signing of [[Magna Carta]] in June 1215 because at this time they were still rebels who refused to compromise. == Restoration of royal favour == King John acquiesced to Reginald's claims to the de Braose estates in Wales in May 1216. Reginald became Lord of [[Brecon]], [[Abergavenny]], [[Builth]] and held other Marcher Lordships but was also very much a vassal of the Welsh leader [[Llywelyn the Great|Llewelyn Fawr]], Prince of [[Kingdom of Gwynedd|Gwynedd]] who became his father-in-law in 1215 <ref>Brut y Tywysogion</ref> when Reginald married Llywelyn's daughter, [[Gwladus Ddu]]. [[Henry III of England|Henry III]] restored Reginald to favour and the Bramber estates (confiscated by King John) in 1217. == Welsh wars == At this seeming betrayal, Rhys and Owain, Reginald's Welsh nephews who were Princes of [[Deheubarth]], were incensed and took [[Builth]], except the castle. [[Llywelyn Fawr]] also became angry and his forces besieged [[Brecon]]. Reginald eventually surrendered to Llewelyn and gave up Seinhenydd ([[Swansea]]). By 1221 they were at war again, with Llewelyn again laying siege to [[Builth]]. The siege was relieved by King Henry III's forces. From this time on Llewelyn tended to support the claims of Reginald's nephew [[John de Braose]] concerning the de Braose lands in Wales. Reginald was a witness to the re-issue of [[Magna Carta]] by King Henry III in 1225. He died two or three years later in 1227 or 1228 in [[Brecon]] and was succeeded by his son by his first wife, Grecia Briwere, the ill-fated [[William de Braose (died 1230)|William de Braose, Lord Abergavenny]]. He is buried at [[Brecon Cathedral]]. It may be that the [[Matilda de Braose (Deheubarth)|Matilda de Braose]] who was the wife of [[Rhys Mechyll]], [[Prince of Deheubarth]] was the daughter of Reginald. ==See also== *[[House of Braose]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *Complete Peerage, G E Cokayne, Vol 1 pages 21â€“22 for the family of Reginald {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Braose, Reginald de | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1228 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Braose, Reginald de}} [[Category:1228 deaths]] [[Category:Anglo-Normans]] [[Category:Anglo-Normans in Wales]] [[Category:Barons in the Peerage of England]] [[Category:History of Swansea]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]
